segment.text: A married man left for work early one Friday afternoon.
(and his paycheck) partying with the boys.
When he finally returned home on Sunday night,
he ran into a barrage of epithets from his wife.
After a couple of hours of nagging and berating, his wife asked "How would you like it
if you didn't see me for a couple of days?!?"
and the man didn't see his wife.
Tuesday and Wednesday went by with the same result.
the swelling went down a bit
and he could see her a little, just out of the corner of his left eye.
2. Prepositions are not words to end sentences with.
7. Parenthetical words however must be enclosed in commas.
8. It is wrong to ever split an infinitive.
10. Do not use a foreign word
when there is an adequate English quid pro quo.
13. Comparisons are as bad as cliches.
don't use more words than necessary;
18. Exaggeration is a billion times worse than understatement.
20. Analogies in writing are like feathers on a snake
21. The passive voice should not be used.
22. Go around the barn at high noon to avoid colloquialisms.
23. Take the bull by the hand
not one in a million can do it effectively.
when a diminutive alternative would suffice.
28. Subject and verb always has to agree.
29. It behooves you to avoid archaic expressions.
30. Placing a comma between subject and predicate, is not correct.
31. Use your spell checker to avoid mispelling
34. Use the apostrophe in it's proper place
35. Don't never use no double negatives.
36. Poofread carefully to see if you any words out.
37. Hopefully, you will use words correctly, irregardless of how others use them.
40. Don't indulge in sesquipedalian lexicological construction
41. A writer must not shift your point of view.
43. Place pronouns as close as possible, especially in long sentences, as of 10 or more words, to their antecedents.
45. If any word is improper at the end of a sentence, a linking verb is.
47. Everyone should be careful to use a singular pronoun with singular nouns in their writing.
48. Always pick on the correct idiom.
49. The adverb always follows the verb.
50. And always be sure to finish what
Freddy had never seen a plate of Jell-O.
He sat there at the dinner table
staring at it for a long moment,
the boy drew back in amazement.
While proudly showing off his new apartment to friends, a college student led the way into the den.
"What is the big brass gong and hammer for?"
then proceeded to give the gong a room
Suddenly, someone screamed from the other side of the wall,
An elderly Hutterite couple with their son went into town for the first time.
Eventually they ended up in a tall office building.
The wife wandered off to look at something
while the boy and his father became attracted to a shiny wall
They kept seeing people go in
when he saw an old lady get into the shiny box ,
the lights flashed on and off again
and then a few minutes later a gorgeous blonde stepped out.
Every morning for years, at about 11:30, the telephone operator in a small Sierra-Nevada town received a call from a man
One day the operator summed up nerve enough to ask him why the regularity.
"Every day I have to blow the whistle at noon
so I call you to get the exact time."
"Because all this time we've been setting our clock by your whistle.
I am making lot$ of friend$ and $tudying very hard.
With all my $tuff, I $imply can't think of anything
you can ju$t $end me a card,
a$ I would love to hear from you.
that astroNOmy, ecoNOmics, and oceaNOgraphy are eNOugh to keep even an hoNOr student busy.
that the pursuit of kNOwledge is a NOble task,
and you can never study eNOugh.
